title: Vendor platform offers meetings for charity
text:
The suppliers that are expected to be seeking meetings include information security services firm Dell EMC, software testing company Tricentis, enterprise solutions provider Global Cloud Xchange and analytics and artificial intelligence group 247.AI.

The scheme is the brainchild of Carl Gough, a former technology salesman and founder of Meetmagic, a platform that connects procurers and suppliers.

The goal is to organise 500 Starlight "meetings for good" in 12 months, raising $350,000 to help give happiness to 9000 seriously ill children in hospital, Mr Gough said.

Venture capitalist Mark Carnegie says his office receives hundreds of calls a month from would-be suppliers. Fairfax

Airwallex president Lucy Liu had little hesitation in signing up for the scheme.

"I quickly jumped on board. I thought it was a really good idea," Ms Liu said, adding that she received 20 to 30 meeting requests a week from would-be suppliers.

Mr Matuszczak said he received more than 40 vendor requests for lunch, coffee or dinner every day, so it made sense for him to schedule a few meetings this way.

Mr Carnegie said: " I thought he [Mr Gough] was a good guy trying to do a good thing. Our office gets hundreds of calls a month."

Advertisement

Ms Liu said she had pledged one meeting and would wait to see the quality of suppliers that came on board. But she was optimistic.

"I think the quality of the people should be fairly good compared to what you normally get, because they are paying." She said she was frustrated by templated messages sent by suppliers, with no thought given to the nature of her business.

Mr Gough originally set up Meetmagic in 2017, at the time distributing money to several charities. He ran out of cash and went into full-time employment, but six months ago Paul Keen, the head of software engineering at Qantas, offered to put him in touch with Starlight to see if they could use the Meetmagic platform together to raise funds for the charity.
description: The aim is to raise $350,000 to help children with cancer by connecting executives with service providers
